questions.text: Due to which phenomenon, B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing 

 

  • B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.
  • Alternative splicing is the process that selectively removes introns or exons, or parts thereof, to generate multiple messenger RNAs (mRNAs) from a single precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA).
  • Humoral immunity is mediated by antibodies, which are produced by B lymphocytes. 
  • Upon maturation, B lymphocytes produce IgM as the first type of immunoglobulin, followed by immunoglobulin IgG, IgE, and IgA, as a result of irreversible rearrangement of the immunoglobulin gene after activation. 
  • In contrast, the IgM-to-IgD transition is produced through alternative splicing of a long primary mRNA transcript from the Ig heavy chain gene, IGH. The nuclear RNA-binding protein, HuR, is well known for its function in mRNA splicing and nuclear export. 

 

Other Option:

 

Options A. Somatic hypermutation and C. Affinity maturation: Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and anti-pathogen activity and is the result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding.

 

Option D. Allelic exclusion: Allelic exclusion is a process by which only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other allele is silenced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B cells express both IgM and IgD through alternative RNA splicing, allowing the simultaneous expression of these two immunoglobulins.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to blood in his stool, which the parents noticed when changing his diaper. The infant has had no previous bleeding and has been eating and drinking normally. He has a history of recurrent otitis media, frequent herpes labialis, and 2 episodes of pneumonia. On examination, the patient is well developed, well nourished, and has a fair complexion. He has eczema on his cheeks, trunk, and extremities. Scattered petechiae are also visible on his lower extremities.  Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 24,000/mm³ and a leukocyte count of 9,000/mm³. Peripheral smear confirms the low platelet count and that the platelets are small. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following processes is most likely affected by this patient's gene mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytoskeleton regulation 

 

This patient has Wiskott–Aldrich Syndrome (WAS). It is caused by mutations in the WASP gene, which regulates the actin cytoskeleton in hematopoietic cells. This leads to:

 

  • Small platelets → bleeding
  • Immunodeficiency → recurrent infections
  • Eczema → atopic features

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Antibody class switching: Hyper IgM syndrome; recurrent infections but platelets normal.

 

Option C. DNA repair: Ataxia-telangiectasia or Fanconi anemia; ataxia, telangiectasias, or bone marrow failure, not small platelets with eczema.

 

Option D. Maturation of T cells: SCID; severe early infections without small platelets or eczema.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for 2 days of fever, cough, and worsening shortness of breath. The patient's parents report that he recently recovered from prolonged diarrhea due to Giardia infection. Medical history is significant for recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics since age 6 months and lobar pneumonia requiring hospitalization. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 °F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 60/min. Physical examination reveals small tonsils and crackles in the lower lobe of the right lung. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abnormal B-lymphocyte maturation

 

This patient most likely has Bruton's X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), caused by mutations in the BTK gene, which is necessary for B-cell maturation. Features include:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections (otitis media, pneumonia)
  • Infections with Giardia (GI protozoa)
  • Absent or small tonsils and lymph nodes due to lack of mature B cells
  • Lab: markedly low or absent immunoglobulins

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Adenosine deaminase deficiency: Causes SCID; severe infections in early infancy affecting both T and B cells.

 

Option C. Complement deficiency: Predisposes mainly to Neisseria infections or immune complex diseases, not recurrent respiratory infections from common bacteria.

 

Option D. Impaired oxidative burst: Chronic granulomatous disease; leads to infections with catalase-positive bacteria and fungi, not Giardia.

questions.text: Which of the following does not provide passive immunity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoid

 

  • Toxoids are inactivated bacterial toxins that stimulate the body to produce its own antibodies, providing active immunity, not passive.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Antitoxin: Contains preformed antibodies against toxins, providing immediate passive immunity.

 

Option B. Maternal Monoclonal Antibody: Provides passive immunity to the infant by transferring ready-made antibodies.

 

Option C. IgA: Present in breast milk and mucosal secretions, giving the infant passive protection against infections.

questions.text: Which of the following mediators of inflammation is an example of a C-X-C chemokine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-8

 

IL-8 is a C-X-C chemokine that primarily attracts neutrophils to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Lipoxin LXA-4: A lipid mediator that resolves inflammation, not a chemokine.

 

Option C. Lymphotactin: A C chemokine, attracts lymphocytes, not neutrophils.

 

Option D. Fractalkine: A CX3C chemokine, involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells 

 

Mature dendritic cells are professional antigen-presenting cells that express high levels of MHC and costimulatory molecules, efficiently activating naive T-cells.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells: Present antigens to B-cells in germinal centers, not naive T-cells.

 

Option C. B lymphocytes: Can present antigen but are less effective at stimulating naive T-cells.

 

Option D. NK cell: Part of innate immunity; do not stimulate T-cells.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice lack a thymus, leading to absence of T-cells, which are crucial for rejecting foreign grafts.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. B cell: B-cells are present; deficiency is not the reason for xenograft acceptance.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Only T-cells are absent; B-cells are normal.

 

Option D. NK cell: NK cells are present; they provide partial innate immunity but cannot fully reject xenografts.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is evaluated for recurrent infections. He was born at term after a normal pregnancy. His mother states, "He is always sick with something and is constantly on antibiotics." The patient's past medical records indicate multiple episodes of otitis media, skin infections, and pneumonia. Incision and drainage of his skin infections revealed Staphylococcus aureus on bacterial culture but no purulence. Laboratory testing reveals absent CD18 antigens on the surface of leukocytes. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Persistent leukocytosis

 

The patient has Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD-1) due to absent CD18. Neutrophils cannot migrate to infection sites, leading to persistent high WBC counts despite ongoing infections.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Infection following live-virus vaccines: Seen in T-cell immunodeficiencies

 

Option B. Infection with Neisseria: Seen in complement deficiencies.

 

Option D. Small or absent lymph nodes: Seen in X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) allows thymic medullary epithelial cells to express peripheral tissue antigens, enabling negative selection of self-reactive T-cells and preventing autoimmunity.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Involved in T-cell lineage commitment, not self-tolerance.

 

Option B. E2A: Transcription factor required for B-cell development.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Required for V(D)J recombination in T- and B-cell receptor formation.

questions.text: Match the CD markers-
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

 

Pluripotent stem cells: CD34 is a classical marker.

 

Megakaryocytes: CD41/CD42 are specific for platelet lineage.

 

Erythrocytes: CD71 is the transferrin receptor on developing RBCs.

 

Monocytes: CD14/CD64 are monocyte/macrophage markers.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 um3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA crosslink repair

 

The patient most likely has Fanconi anemia, caused by defects in DNA crosslink repair. It presents with pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, café-au-lait spots, and growth retardation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Mutation in WAS protein: Causes Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome; features include small platelets, eczema, and recurrent infections, but not congenital anomalies like café-au-lait spots.

 

Option C. Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia: Usually presents with blast cells on peripheral smear, rapid onset, and bone pain; not typical congenital anomalies.

 

Option D. Post Viral Autoimmune reaction: Usually causes isolated cytopenias transiently, not multiple congenital anomalies or chronic pancytopenia.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structure and function of immunoglobulins that are transmitted across the placenta from mother to fetus. The structure indicated by the arrow is primarily responsible for which of the following immunological events?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixing of complement

 

The arrow points to the Fc region of the IgG molecule. This part of the antibody is primarily responsible for fixing complement via the classical pathway, allowing activation of immune effector functions such as cell lysis and phagocytosis.

 

Fc = helps in placental transfer, It binds specifically to the neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn) expressed on placental syncytiotrophoblast cells

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Formation of dimer: This is characteristic of IgA, not IgG.

 

Option B. Binding to mast cells: Mostly associated with IgE.

 

Option D. Attachment to antigen: Occurs at the Fab region, not the Fc region.

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.text: Casoni reaction is seen in patients with hydatid cyst. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is the only heat stable antibody

 

The antibody involved is IgE, which is heat labile, not heat stable.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Levels are raised in helminthic infections: IgE levels increase during parasitic infections.

 

Option C. It does not pass the placental barrier: IgE cannot cross the placenta.

 

Option D. It has a half-life of 1-5 days: IgE has a short half-life of about 1–2 days in circulation.

choices.text: CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide
CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells
CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells
CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old medical student undergoes a tuberculin skin test (TST) as part of a routine health check. He is asymptomatic with no history of recent fever, weight loss, or cough. He receives an intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD) on the inner surface of his forearm. After 48 hours, a raised, erythematous induration measuring 18 mm is observed at the injection site. Which of the following interactions is critical to the development of this patient’s skin reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

 

The TST is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by CD4+ T-cells. Interaction of CD28 on T-cells with CD80/86 on antigen-presenting dendritic cells provides the costimulatory signal essential for T-cell activation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide: Involved in innate immune response to Gram-negative bacteria, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.

 

Option B. CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells: Mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), not TST reaction.

 

Option C. CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells: Involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration, not the critical T-cell activation in TST.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes c & d) is shown below (Boxes a & b are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgM syndrome 

 

The flow cytometry analysis shows that the patient (boxes c & d) has normal numbers of B cells (CD19+) as seen in box c, but box d reveals a significant reduction or absence of CD40 ligand (CD40L) expression on T cells. This pattern is typical of Hyper IgM syndrome, an immunodeficiency caused by a defect in CD40L, preventing class switching of immunoglobulins. Patients present with recurrent bacterial infections and opportunistic infections like Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia due to impaired humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

 

Other Option:
 

Option A. Bare lymphocytes: Bare lymphocyte syndrome presents with combined immunodeficiency due to lack of MHC molecules and would show decreased B and T cells.
 

Option B. Chronic granulocyte deficiency: Chronic granulocyte deficiency affects neutrophils and not lymphocyte populations.
 

Option D. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves T cell deficiency due to thymic hypoplasia, not B cell or CD40L abnormalities.

questions.text:
Arrange the following sentences in the correct order for activation of B cells.

 

  1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides.
  2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation.
  3. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur.
  4. Antigen binding to B cell receptor.
  5. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4, 1, 5, 3, 2 

 

  • 4. Antigen binding to B cell receptor: B cell recognizes the antigen.
  • 1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides: B cell presents antigen to T-helper cell.
  • 5. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD40 on B cells: Provides costimulatory signal for B-cell activation.
  • 3. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur: → Enhances antibody diversity and function.
  • 2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation: Produces high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: All of the following are the part of the innate immunity except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B lymphocytes 

 

B lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system, producing antigen-specific antibodies after activation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Alpha defensins:Antimicrobial peptides that provide immediate defense against pathogens.

 

Option C. Gamma Delta T lymphocytes: Bridge innate and adaptive immunity; respond rapidly to non-peptide antigens.

 

Option D. Lectin pathway: A complement activation pathway of innate immunity.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office with gait instability. Since age 12, the patient has had mild weakness and "clumsiness" in her lower limbs that have progressed. Physical examination reveals kyphoscoliosis ,pes cavus. Joint position and vibration sense are also impaired. Further evaluation reveals that she is suffering from an inherited disease. This patient is at greatest risk of dying from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiomyopathy

 

  • The patient most likely has Friedreich ataxia, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by frataxin deficiency. Complications include hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is the leading cause of death in these patients.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: Associated with Marfan syndrome, not Friedreich ataxia.

 

Option B. Brain tumor: Not characteristic of Friedreich ataxia.

 

Option D. Intracranial bleeding: Not a common cause of death in this condition.

questions.text: Match the following with types of hypersensitivity:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

  1. A 38-year-old female with double vision and mass in the mediastinum: Type 2 hypersensitivity (B) (Myasthenia gravis—antibody-mediated against acetylcholine receptors)
  2. Graft kidney showing mononuclear cell infiltrates with C4d deposition in peritubular capillaries on IF: Type 2 hypersensitivity (B) (Hyperacute and acute humoral rejection—antibody mediated with complement activation)
  3. Renal biopsy in a patient with SLE presenting with hematuria shows thickened vessel walls with pink-staining material
     → Type 3 hypersensitivity (C)
     (Immune complex-mediated—SLE nephritis)
  4. Casoni test in a patient with hydatid cyst: Type 1 hypersensitivity (A) (Skin test—immediate hypersensitivity reaction)

choices.text: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated if platelet count <40,000 

 

The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle set. Bone marrow biopsy is not absolutely contraindicated if platelet count is below 40,000, though relative caution is warranted and transfusion may be considered. Breath holding is required to minimize movement during the procedure, which can be performed with the patient in lateral or prone position. The biopsy aids diagnosis of infiltrative or granulomatous marrow diseases.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Breath holding is required: Breath holding stabilizes the patient during aspiration.

 

Option C. Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position: Both lateral and prone positions are accepted for posterior iliac crest biopsy.

 

Option D. Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease: The procedure is essential for diagnosing infiltrative and granulomatous diseases.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

  1. Swan neck deformity with activation of caspase-1, 4, and release of IL-1β in synovial fluid: Pyroptosis (A) (A form of inflammatory programmed cell death involving caspase-1 and IL-1β release)
  2. Dysregulation of glutathione peroxidase 4 and increased lipid peroxidation in a chemo-resistant breast tumor: Ferroptosis (D) (Iron-dependent lipid peroxidation-mediated cell death regulated by glutathione peroxidase 4)
  3. Radiation induced activation of caspase 9 and 3: Apoptosis (C) (Mitochondrial intrinsic pathway caspase cascade in regulated cell death)
  4. In sepsis, TNF-alpha mediated activation of receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 disrupts plasma membrane integrity causing cell swelling: Necroptosis (B)(A programmed necrosis pathway involving receptor interacting protein kinases) note that Necroptosis is CasPase INDEPENDENT

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the OPD due to severe foot pain. The patient attended a wedding reception where he drank several alcoholic beverages, then woke the following morning with pain. He has a long history of gouty arthritis, and his current symptoms are similar to previous flares of the disease. The patient is started on a new medication for gout that provides significant relief of his symptoms, but he returns to the clinic a week later with diarrhea and persistent nausea. The drug used in this patient most likely affects which of the following cell structure s?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoskeleton

 

The patient was likely treated with colchicine, which relieves acute gout by binding tubulin and inhibiting microtubule polymerization, thus disrupting the cytoskeleton in neutrophils and reducing inflammation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Golgi apparatus: Not targeted by colchicine; involved in protein processing and trafficking.

 

Option C. Nucleus: Colchicine does not directly affect nuclear function.

 

Option D. Peroxisomes: Not affected by colchicine; involved in lipid metabolism and reactive oxygen species detoxification

questions.text: Which of the following neurodegenerative disease has misfolded superoxide dismutase 1 inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 

 

Mutations in SOD1 cause protein misfolding and aggregation in motor neurons, contributing to neuronal death in ALS.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Friedreich ataxia: Caused by frataxin deficiency, not SOD1 inclusions.

 

Option C. Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy: Caused by androgen receptor gene CAG repeat expansion, not SOD1.

 

Option D. Multiple system atrophy: Characterized by alpha-synuclein inclusions, not SOD1.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty
  2. Weber-Fechner law describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity 
  3. Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. 
  4. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All statements are correct 

 

  • 1. Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty → Leptin signals adequate energy stores to the hypothalamus, allowing pubertal onset.
  • 2. Weber-Fechner law → Describes the logarithmic relationship between stimulus magnitude and perceived intensity.
  • 3. Golgi complex in serous acinar cells → Located in the supranuclear cytoplasm, involved in protein processing and secretion.
  • 4. Ganglion cells as third-order neurons → In the optic pathway, ganglion cells transmit visual signals from the retina to the lateral geniculate nucleus.

choices.text: Cyclin B- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin D
Cyclin E- Cyclin B- Cyclin A- Cyclin D
Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B
Cyclin B- Cyclin A- Cyclin E- Cyclin D

questions.text: Arrange in sequence the cyclins at different stages of the cell cycle starting from the G1 phase.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B 

 

  • Cyclin D: G1 phase, drives progression through G1.
  • Cyclin E: G1/S transition, initiates DNA replication.
  • Cyclin A: S phase and G2, promotes DNA synthesis and prepares for mitosis.
  • Cyclin B: M phase, required for entry into mitosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes? 

 

  1. KIT has increased expression in GIST.
  2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
  3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas.
  4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

  • 1. KIT has increased expression in GIST: True; KIT (CD117) mutations drive gastrointestinal stromal tumors.
  • 3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas: True; HER2/neu (ERBB2) amplification promotes breast cancer progression.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

  • 2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma: False; KRAS mutations are more common in non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).
  • 4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers: False; PDGFR-β is often overexpressed in certain cancers, not specifically suppressed in colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
Among the following, which cells have both MHC class I and MHC class II? 

 

  1. NK cells
  2. B-lymphocytes
  3. Dendritic cells
  4. Platelets
  5. RBC
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3

 

  • B-lymphocytes: Express MHC I and II, present antigens to helper T-cells.
  • Dendritic cells: Professional antigen-presenting cells expressing both MHC I and II.

 

Incorrect options:

 

  • 1. NK cells: Express MHC I but not MHC II.
  • 4. Platelets: Express MHC I only, no MHC II.
  • 5. RBC: Lack both MHC I and II.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by Trinucleotide repeat mutations involving coding regions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myotonic dystrophy

 

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by CTG repeat expansion in the 3′ untranslated region (non-coding region) of the DMPK gene.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Spinocerebellar ataxia: Caused by CAG repeat expansions in coding regions.

 

Option C. Huntington disease: Caused by CAG repeats in the coding region of the HTT gene.

 

Option D. Kennedy disease: Caused by CAG repeats in the coding region of the androgen receptor gene.

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion 

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor and typically does not show perineural invasion. It is infact shown by adenoid cystic carcinoma

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Myoepithelial cells: Present; contribute to the tumor’s pleomorphic histology.

 

Option B. Keratin pearls: Can be seen in areas of squamous differentiation within the tumor.

 

Option C. Chondroid differentiation: Common; gives the characteristic cartilage-like stroma.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. In nutmeg liver, dark areas represent necrosis due to passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.
  2. Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity. 
  3. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure lead to development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.
  4. Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All statements are correct

 

1. In nutmeg liver, dark areas represent necrosis due to passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue: Dark areas = congested/necrotic, pale areas = viable tissue.

 

2. Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity: Histone deacetylases that improve insulin sensitivity and metabolic regulation.

 

3. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure lead to development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin: Complication of long-term hemodialysis.

 

4. Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability: Most common genetic hypercoagulable disorder.

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? 

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
  5. Causes nuclear fragmentation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 

 

  • 1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrotic cells lose membrane integrity.
  • 2. Induces inflammation: Necrosis releases intracellular contents, triggering inflammatory response.
  • 3. Swelling of the cell: Necrotic cells often swell (oncosis) before lysis.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

  • 4. Can be seen physiologically: False; necrosis is pathological, not physiological.
  • 5. Causes nuclear fragmentation: More characteristic of apoptosis, not typical necrosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has frequent episodes of facial edema around his lips. It usually occurs after an emotional stressor. He also has a family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is the main mediator of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradykinin

 

The patient likely has hereditary angioedema, where bradykinin is the main mediator causing vascular permeability and swelling.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Leukotriene: Involved in allergic reactions and asthma, not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. Prostaglandin E2: Mediates fever and inflammation, not primary in angioedema.

 

Option D. Histamine: Responsible for allergic urticaria, not bradykinin-mediated hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child brought to OPD with complaints of fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull revealed multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for S100, CD1a. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis 

 

The clinical scenario of a child with fever, rash, bone pain, and multiple lytic skull lesions, together with the skin biopsy showing cells with nuclear grooves and numerous eosinophils, and immunohistochemistry positive for S100 and CD1a, is classic for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Rosai-Dorfman disease: Characterized by massive lymphadenopathy with S100+, but not CD1a+, and lacks the nuclear grooves.

 

Option B. Kimura disease: Presents as chronic subcutaneous inflammation and eosinophilia, not nuclear grooves or CD1a+ staining.

 

Option D. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma: Shows foam cells and Touton giant cells, not nuclear grooves or CD1a positivity.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor 

 

Adrenal cortical tumors are of cortical origin and do not contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Contains neurosecretory granules producing calcitonin.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Some hormone-secreting adenomas have neurosecretory granules.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Derived from chromaffin tissue, contains neurosecretory granules.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. MCL 1 is an anti-apoptotic gene belonging to the BCL-2 family.
  2. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography in amyloidosis
  3. Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is caused by the point mutation of the SRY gene. 
  4. Diaminobenzidine is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

  1. MCL-1 → Anti-apoptotic member of the BCL-2 family.
  2. Beta-pleated sheets → Characteristic amyloid structure seen on X-ray crystallography.
  3. Complete gonadal dysgenesis → Usually caused by deletions or point mutations in SRY
  4. Diaminobenzidine (DAB) → Commonly used chromogen for peroxidase reactions in IHC, producing a brown precipitate.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

The clinical presentation of proptosis in a young child, along with histopathology showing desmin-positive tumor cells on immunohistochemistry, is characteristic of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Desmin is a muscle-specific intermediate filament and a marker for rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Typically CD99 positive, not desmin positive.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Not associated with desmin positivity or proptosis as a primary feature.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Mostly presents intraocularly, not with desmin positivity.

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

 

Renal transplantation has high initial costs, but becomes cost-effective compared to dialysis typically after 1–2 years.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year: Slightly overestimated; one-year graft survival is high but usually around 85–90%.

 

Option B. Life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant: Improves survival, but not exactly doubled.

 

Option D. The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years: Chronic rejection remains difficult to treat, with limited therapeutic advancements.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation?

 

  1. Selectin 
  2. ICAM-1
  3. CD31
  4. IL-8
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

  • 1. Selectin: Mediates rolling of leukocytes along the endothelium.
  • 2. ICAM-1: Facilitates firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelial surface.
  • 3. CD31: Involved in diapedesis, allowing leukocytes to migrate through the endothelium.
  • 4. IL-8: Acts as a chemotactic factor, guiding leukocytes to the site of inflammation.

questions.text: A CECT of a 35-year-old male is reported as “Hypervascular anterior mediastinal mass”. The tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymph node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Castleman disease

 

The histopathology slide demonstrates lymph node architecture with prominent lymphoid follicles and expanded mantle zones, characteristic of Castleman disease. The associated clinical description of a hypervascular anterior mediastinal mass further supports this diagnosis, as Castleman disease often presents as a solitary mass in the mediastinum and can show “onion-skin” appearance of lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Angiolymphoma: Rare, does not show these features.

 

Option B. Hodgkin's lymphoma: Typically has Reed-Sternberg cells and different lymph node pattern.

 

Option C. Thymoma: Originates from thymic epithelial cells, not lymphoid tissue, and histology is distinct.

questions.text:
Which mediators involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity?

 

  1. Mast cell
  2. Histamine
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Prostaglandins
  5. Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

  • 1. Mast cells: Activated by IgE, initiate the early phase.
  • 2. Histamine: Released from mast cells, causing vasodilation, increased permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • 4. Prostaglandins: Lipid mediators contributing to vasodilation and bronchoconstriction.
  • 5. Leukotrienes:  Lipid mediators causing smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and chemotaxis.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

  • 3. Neutrophils are involved in the late phase, not early phase.

questions.text:
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: 

 

  1. Natural killer (NK) cells 
  2. Macrophages
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Eosinophils
  5. CD4 lymphocytes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • 1. NK cells: Express FcγRIII (CD16); kill IgG-coated target cells.
  • 3. Neutrophils: Mediate ADCC via Fc receptors.
  • 4. Eosinophils: Kill IgE-coated parasites by releasing major basic protein.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

  • 2. Macrophages: Mainly phagocytose via opsonization, not classical ADCC.
  • 5. CD4 lymphocytes: Provide help via cytokines, not direct ADCC.

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

 

Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated; they result from direct mast cell/basophil degranulation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Involves degranulation of mast cells: True, but through non-IgE pathways.

 

Option C. Can occur on first exposure: True, since prior sensitization is not required.

 

Option D. Most commonly caused by NSAIDs: True, NSAIDs are frequent triggers along with radiocontrast agents and opioids.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

 

  1. TxA2 has platelet aggregating and vasoconstricting effect
  2. Lipoxin B4 inhibits inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.
  3. Il-1, Il-18, TNF are pyrogenic cytokines
  4. C3 can be activated in both common as well as alternative pathways
  5. T cells with a TCR composed of a γ and δ subunit are found associated with GI mucosa
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

  • 1. TxA₂ has platelet aggregating and vasoconstricting effect: True, it promotes thrombosis and vasoconstriction.
  • 2. Lipoxin B₄ inhibits neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion: True, it is an anti-inflammatory mediator.
  • 4. C3 can be activated in both classical and alternative pathways: True, it is central to complement activation.
  • 5. γδ T cells are associated with GI mucosa: True, they act as intraepithelial lymphocytes.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

  • 3. IL-1, IL-18, TNF are pyrogenic cytokines: IL-1 & TNF are pyrogenic, but IL-18 mainly induces IFN-γ and is not a classical pyrogen.

questions.text: Identify the disorder inherited by the following pedigree:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NARP

 

The pedigree shows inheritance only through females with affected males and females in each generation, consistent with mitochondrial inheritance. NARP (Neuropathy, Ataxia, and Retinitis Pigmentosa) is a mitochondrial disorder inherited exclusively from the mother; all offspring of affected mothers may show the disease, while offspring of affected fathers are unaffected.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Marfan syndrome: Autosomal dominant, would be seen in both males and females, but not restricted to maternal inheritance.

 

Option B and C. Hemophilia A and C: X-linked recessive; mostly affects males, and would show different pattern in pedigree.

questions.text: You work under a research scientist who is working on determining the association of adenocarcinoma of pancreas with a compound X. He uses a test whose steps are shown in the image below to determine the mutagenic effect and potential carcinogenicity of compound X. What is this test that he has used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ames test

 

The image shows the classic Ames test, which is used to assess the mutagenic and carcinogenic potential of a compound by observing its ability to induce genetic mutations in a strain of Salmonella that requires histidine for growth. An increased number of revertant colonies (his- to his+) after exposure to the compound, especially compared to the control, indicates that the compound X may cause mutations.

 

Other Option:


Option A. CGH (Comparative Genomic Hybridization): detects genomic abnormalities, not mutagenicity.


Option B. Micro nucleus test: evaluates chromosomal damage, not point mutations in bacteria.


Option C. Microtox bio-assay: measures toxicity using bioluminescent bacteria, not mutagenicity.

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

  • Light blue (Citrate tube): Collected first to avoid contamination with clot activators or EDTA that can affect coagulation studies.
  • Red (Plain tube, no anticoagulant): Collected next for serology/chemistry, avoids interference from EDTA or fluoride.
  • Lavender (EDTA tube): Collected later for hematology; prevents EDTA carryover from affecting earlier tests.
  • Grey (Fluoride oxalate tube): Collected last for glucose/lactate estimation, since fluoride inhibits glycolysis and would interfere with other tests if drawn earlier.

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methanol 

 

Methanol Not a crosslinking fixative; it is a precipitating/coagulant fixative that denatures proteins rather than crosslinking them.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Glutaraldehyde: Crosslinking fixative; links proteins by forming covalent bonds.

 

Option B. Formaldehyde: Crosslinking fixative; creates methylene bridges between proteins.

 

Option D. Osmium tetroxide: Crosslinking fixative; reacts with lipids and proteins, mainly used in EM.

choices.text: Donor T cells in the graft

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, a 55-year-old man develops a severely pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, and profuse diarrhea. He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae. There is a generalized maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and lower extremities, and desquamation of both soles. His serum alanine aminotransferase is 115 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase is 97 U/L, and serum total bilirubin is 2.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Donor T cells in the graft

 

Clinical scenario: Patient develops rash, diarrhoea, jaundice, and liver enzyme elevation 2 weeks post–allogeneic stem cell transplant → classic for acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

 

  • Mechanism: Donor T cells in the graft recognize recipient (host) antigens as foreign and mount an immune attack against host tissues (skin, liver, GI tract).

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies: Seen in graft rejection, not GVHD.

 

Option C. Proliferating transplanted B cells: May cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (EBV-related), not GVHD.

 

Option D. Activated recipient T cells: Would mediate host-versus-graft rejection, but here the host marrow has been ablated.

questions.text: Which of the following stains are used to visualize the specific fibers present in the following cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verhoeff's stain

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, identified by the presence of densely packed chondrocytes and a matrix containing elastic fibers. Verhoeff’s stain is specifically used to visualize elastic fibers, turning them black and allowing for detailed study of their distribution in tissues like elastic cartilage.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Bielchowsky stain: Used for nerve fibers.

 

 

Option C. GMS silver stain: Used for fungi.

 

 

Option D. Alcian Blue stain: Used for acidic mucopolysaccharides, not specifically elastic fibers.

choices.text: Is both intra and extra cellular
Can happen due to nutrient deprivation
Phagolysosome fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

questions.text: All of following are the correct statement about autophagy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Is both intra and extra cellular

 

Autophagy is a strictly intracellular process, not extracellular.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Can happen due to nutrient deprivation: True; autophagy is upregulated during starvation to recycle cellular components.

 

Option C. Phagophore/autophagosome fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome: True; degradation occurs here.

 

Option D. Bound by a double membrane: True; autophagosomes are typically double-membrane bound vesicles.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about nitric oxide?

  1. eNOS is constitutively expressed and helps regulate vascular tone.
  2. NO helps in generation of free radicals in neutrophil at the time of inflammation 
  3. Interferon-γ (IFN-γ) or microbial products can activate inducible NOS.
  4. Synthesis of NO requires NOS action on arginine.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4 

 

  • 1. eNOS is constitutively expressed and helps regulate vascular tone → True, not false; eNOS is always active in endothelium.
  • 3. IFN-γ or microbial products can activate inducible NOS → True, iNOS is induced by cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ) and endotoxin.
  • 4. Synthesis of NO requires NOS action on arginine → True, arginine → citrulline + NO via nitric oxide synthase.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

  • 2. NO helps in generation of free radicals in neutrophil at the time of inflammation → Not true; neutrophils use NADPH oxidase to make superoxide, not NO.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium dichromate

 

Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) can be measured through various methods, including gas chromatography. For accurate measurement of BAC, the blood sample is typically collected in a gray-top vial. This vial contains a mixture of sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate.

 

Sodium fluoride acts as a preservative and prevents glycolysis, which could otherwise lower the concentration of alcohol in the blood sample.

 

However, when using the potassium dichromate test for BAC, potassium dichromate is included in the sample collection tube. In this test, potassium dichromate, which is orange in color, reacts with ethanol present in the blood sample. This reaction converts ethanol to acetic acid and simultaneously reduces potassium dichromate to chromium, which turns the solution green. The intensity of the green color directly correlates with the alcohol concentration in the sample, providing a visual indication of BAC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin + EDTA: This combination is generally used as an anticoagulant in blood samples for various laboratory tests but is not specifically used for BAC measurement.

 

Option C. Heparin: While heparin is an anticoagulant, it is not used in the collection tubes for blood alcohol concentration testing.

 

Option D. Sodium citrate: Sodium citrate is also an anticoagulant, commonly used in coagulation studies, but it is not relevant for BAC measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride and potassium dichromate are the substances used in the tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement. Potassium dichromate reacts with ethanol in the blood sample, facilitating the detection and quantification of alcohol concentration

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman has experienced pain in the area around the left knee for the past 6 weeks. MRI shows a well-circumscribed 4-cm mass superior and inferior to the patella. The mass is within soft tissue, without bony erosion. A biopsy of the mass is obtained and on microscopic examination shows a biphasic pattern of spindle cells and epithelial cells forming glands. Karyotypic analysis of tumor cells shows a t(X;18) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Synovial sarcoma

 

Characterized by biphasic pattern (spindle cells + epithelial gland-like structures) and t(X;18) translocation, most common near large joints in young to middle-aged adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmoid tumor: Fibroblastic proliferation, locally aggressive, no glandular structures or t(X;18).

 

Option B. Leiomyosarcoma: Malignant smooth muscle tumor, shows fascicles of spindle cells with blunt-ended nuclei, no biphasic pattern or translocation.

 

Option C. Mesothelioma: Malignancy of pleura/peritoneum, not localized to knee, no specific t(X;18).

choices.text: Composed mainly of red cells (Red Thrombi)

questions.text: All are features of venous thrombus, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caused by turbulent blood flow

 

Venous thrombi are caused by stasis of blood, not turbulence (which is seen in arterial thrombi).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Common in deep leg veins: True, most venous thrombi occur in deep veins of the leg.
 

Option C. Propagate in antegrade manner: True, venous thrombi extend in the direction of blood flow.
 

Option D. Composed mainly of red cells (red thrombi): True, venous thrombi are rich in RBCs and fibrin.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CK7 negative, CK20 negative

 

Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is characteristically negative for both CK7 and CK20.

 

Other Options:


Option A. CK7 positive, CK20 positive: Incorrect, this pattern is typical for some urothelial carcinomas, not RCC.
 

Option B. CK7 negative, CK20 positive: Incorrect, CK20 positivity is not seen in RCC.
 

Option C. CK7 positive, CK20 negative: Incorrect, CK7 can be positive in papillary RCC, but not in clear cell RCC (the most common subtype).

questions.text: Upon reactivation of VZV, the virus is transported through the nerve axon to the skin. Which of the following proteins is most likely involved in the transport process leading to disease recurrence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kinesin

 

Kinesin is the motor protein responsible for anterograde transport of VZV along microtubules from the neuronal cell body to the skin during reactivation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Dynein: Incorrect, dynein mediates retrograde transport (from periphery to neuronal cell body).
 

Option C. Lamin: Incorrect, lamins are nuclear envelope structural proteins, not involved in axonal transport.
 

Option D. Selectin: Incorrect, selectins mediate leukocyte adhesion and rolling, not viral transport.

questions.text: The solid line represents a normal individual, and the dotted line represents this patient. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary polydipsia

 

The graph shows reduced concentration of solute with increased volume in the dotted line compared to the solid line, which represents a normal individual. This pattern is characteristic of primary polydipsia, a condition in which excessive water intake leads to dilute urine (low solute concentration) and high urine volume.image.jpg

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Acute gastrointestinal hemorrhage: Typically causes low urinary volume, not dilute urine.
 

Option B. Diabetes insipidus: Has increased urine volume but with poor concentration ability, not matching the dilution seen here.
 

Option C. Hypertonic saline infusion: Would result in concentrated urine, not dilute.

choices.text: PaCo2 normal, PaO2 normal, pH decreases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low
PaCo2 low, PaO2 normal, pH decreases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low
PaCo2 high, PaO2 low, pH increases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low
PaCo2 low, PaO2 low, pH normal, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low

questions.text: 23-year-old man undergoes exercise physiology testing. He jogs on a treadmill to achieve a moderate-intensity physical activity level based on a target heart rate of 50%-70% of his estimated maximum heart rate. Which of the following is expected at peak exercise?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PaCO₂ low, PaO₂ normal, pH decreases, PvCO₂ high, PvO₂ low: 

 

At peak exercise:

 

PaCO₂ low: Hyperventilation during exercise causes more CO₂ to be blown off.

 

PaO₂ normal: Arterial oxygenation is usually preserved due to efficient gas exchange.

 

pH decreases: Due to lactic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism.

 

PvCO₂ high: More CO₂ is generated by working muscles.

 

PvO₂ low: Increased O₂ extraction by tissues.

 

Other Options:


Option A. PaCo2 normal, PaO2 normal, pH decreases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low: Incorrect, because hyperventilation lowers PaCO₂.
 

Option C. PaCo2 low, PaO2 normal, pH decreases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low: Incorrect, acidosis (↓pH) occurs, not alkalosis; PaO₂ is maintained.
 

Option D. PaCo2 high, PaO2 low, pH increases, PvCo2 high, PvO2 low: Incorrect, PaO₂ remains normal and pH decreases.

questions.text: All of the following are the properties of Renshaw cells except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feedforward inhibition 

 

Renshaw cells are inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord that receive excitatory input from α-motor neurons and, in turn, inhibit the same motor neuron or its neighbors.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Lateral inhibition: Renshaw cells can inhibit neighboring motor neurons, helping sharpen motor signals.
 

Option B. Feedback inhibition: They are activated by motor neurons and send inhibitory signals back, a classic example of feedback inhibition.
 

Option D. Recurrent inhibition: Renshaw cells provide recurrent inhibition of motor neurons via glycine release.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man, who was recently started on risperidone therapy for schizophrenia, comes to the office due to involuntary deviation of his head. There is palpable tightening of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is determined that the patient is experiencing a medication-induced dystonic reaction due to motor neuron hyperactivity. The persistent myocyte stimulation causes a substance to be released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This substance most likely binds to which of the following proteins to cause this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

In acute dystonia caused by antipsychotics (eg, risperidone), excessive stimulation of motor neurons leads to sustained depolarization at the neuromuscular junction.

 

This causes continuous release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via ryanodine receptors.

 

Calcium then binds to troponin C, which moves tropomyosin away from actin’s myosin-binding sites, allowing persistent actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling → sustained muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Actin: Structural protein of thin filaments, but calcium does not bind directly to it.
 

Option B. Myosin: Thick filament motor protein that binds actin once tropomyosin shifts, but it is not the calcium-binding site.
 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Covers myosin-binding sites on actin; calcium binding does not occur here, but calcium binding to troponin moves tropomyosin.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential(RMP) of the nerve is - 70mV. Increased permeability of which ion is responsible for the RMP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP ≈ –70 mV) is mainly determined by the high permeability of the neuronal membrane to potassium (K⁺) at rest.

 

Potassium leak channels allow K⁺ to diffuse out of the cell (down its concentration gradient), leaving behind negatively charged proteins, which stabilizes the negative RMP.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Calcium: Intracellular calcium concentration is very low, but calcium channels are closed at rest; negligible role in RMP.
 

Option B. Sodium: Some Na⁺ leaks in, but at rest the membrane is much less permeable to Na⁺ compared to K⁺.
 

Option D. Chloride: Helps in inhibitory signaling, but does not primarily set the RMP.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

The graph illustrates the response of the gastrocnemius muscle to a single stimulus, typically showing a single twitch contraction. Formula for tetanizing frequency = 100/time taken to reach highest amplitude{tension}. 

 

100/[4-5] = 20-25Hz

 

This frequency is required for individual twitches to merge and produce a smooth, continuous increase in tension.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the steps involved in excitation-contraction coupling of smooth muscle cells.

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Myosin phosphorylation
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Binding of myosin to actin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2-3-1-4

 

Sequence of events in smooth muscle excitation–contraction coupling:

 

2. Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) – Ca²⁺ binds to calmodulin, forming a complex that activates MLCK.

3. Myosin phosphorylation – MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chain, enabling cross-bridge formation.

1. Increased influx of Ca²⁺ into the cell – via voltage-gated, ligand-gated, or stretch-activated Ca²⁺ channels.

4. Binding of myosin to actin – phosphorylated myosin interacts with actin, leading to contraction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. 2-1-3-4: Wrong,phosphorylation cannot occur before MLCK activation.


Option B. 2-1-4-3: Wrong, actin binding occurs only after phosphorylation.
 

Option C. 3-2-1-4: Wrong, Ca²⁺ influx must occur before MLCK activation.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50ml/hr

 

Insensible water loss refers to water lost through skin (evaporation, not sweating) and respiratory tract.

 

Normal insensible water loss is ~500–700 ml/day, which averages to ~50 ml/hr in adults.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. 100 ml/hr: Too high (would be ~2.4 L/day, above normal range).
 

Option B. 150 ml/hr: Very high, exceeds physiologic baseline loss.
 

Option D. 200 ml/hr: Extremely high, pathological rather than normal.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old goes on a month-long trek across the Himalayas. Which of the following physiological adaptations would you expect to see in him at high altitudes following acclimatization?

 

1. Erythropoietin secretion increases

2. Tissue myoglobin decreases

3. Tissue content of cytochrome oxidase increases

4. pH of blood increases
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

At high altitude, acclimatization involves increased erythropoietin secretion (to raise RBC mass), increased tissue cytochrome oxidase (to improve oxidative metabolism), and respiratory alkalosis with raised blood pH due to hyperventilation.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

2. Tissue myoglobin decreases: Incorrect, tissue myoglobin actually increases to enhance oxygen storage and delivery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of unstable angina. Cardiac catheterization shows occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter of the left circumflex artery. Resistance to blood flow in this vessel has increased by what factor relative to a vessel with no occlusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16

 

According to Poiseuille’s law, vascular resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius (R ∝ 1/r⁴).

 

  • A 50% reduction in diameter → radius is also reduced to ½ of original.
  • Resistance factor = (1/(½)4)=1/(1/16)=16

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with diabetes undergoes stress testing. He walks for 7 minutes without chest pain. Peak heart rate is 132/min, BP increases from 95 to 112 mmHg. Which of the following parameters was most likely decreased during peak stress?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total systemic vascular resistance

 

During exercise, cardiac output increases due to ↑HR and ↑stroke volume. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure may rise slightly but does not decrease. Systolic BP rises, not falls. To accommodate increased flow, systemic vascular resistance decreases due to vasodilation in exercising muscles.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cardiac output: Increases during exercise.
 

Option B. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure: Usually stable or mildly ↑, not decreased.


Option C. Systemic systolic blood pressure: Rises, not reduced.

questions.text: In the study of appetite regulation, which of the following polypeptides is known to increase appetite?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuropeptide Y

 

Neuropeptide Y, secreted in the hypothalamus (arcuate nucleus), is a potent orexigenic peptide that stimulates appetite.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Leptin: Decreases appetite (anorexigenic).
 

Option C. Glucagon related peptide 1: Inhibits appetite, enhances satiety.



Option D. Serotonin: Suppresses appetite, especially for carbohydrates.

questions.text: Match the following with the mode of cellular transport:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-D, 5-C, 6-C

Matching the substances with the mode of cellular transport:

 

  1. Oxygen
    → Simple diffusion (A)
    (Oxygen diffuses freely across cell membranes down its concentration gradient)
  2. GLUT (Glucose transporter)
    → Facilitated diffusion (B)
    (GLUT transports glucose without ATP, down its concentration gradient)
  3. SGLT (Sodium-glucose linked transporter)
    → Secondary active transport (D)
    (Uses Na+ gradient to drive glucose uptake against its gradient)
  4. Na+/Iodide symporter
    → Secondary active transport (D)
    (Symporter couples iodide uptake with Na+ moving down its gradient)
  5. Na+/K+ ATPase
    → Primary active transport (C)
    (Uses ATP directly to pump Na+ out and K+ into the cell)
  6. Proton pump
    → Primary active transport (C)
    (ATP-driven transport of protons across membranes)

questions.text: Which of the following regions contain only thick filaments and no thin filaments?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E

 

In the image of the skeletal muscle sarcomere, region E corresponds to the H-zone, which contains only thick filaments (myosin) and no thin filaments (actin). The H-zone is found in the center of the A-band, and thin filaments do not overlap this region, distinguishing it from other sarcomere zones

 

  • A: Z line (Z disc) boundary between adjacent sarcomeres
  • B: I band – contains only thin filaments (actin)
  • C: M line – center of the sarcomere, where thick filaments are anchored
  • D: A band – entire length of thick filaments; includes regions of overlap with thin filaments
  • E: H zone – area with only thick filaments (myosin), no thin filaments

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dynein arm

 

This clinical scenario describes chronic respiratory infections, sinusitis, infertility, and a CT scan demonstrating dextrocardia (heart on the right side), most consistent with Kartagener syndrome (a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia). The disorder results from a defect in the dynein arm, a molecular motor protein essential for ciliary movement. Dysfunctional cilia lead to poor mucociliary clearance, recurrent infections, impaired fertility, and situs inversus (dextrocardia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B. IL-12 receptor and IL-2R gamma chain: Related to immune deficiencies, not ciliary dyskinesia or situs inversus.

 

Option C. NADPH oxidase: Deficient in chronic granulomatous disease, presenting with recurrent catalase-positive infections but not situs inversus or infertility.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

The motor supply of the muscle spindle (shown in the image) is provided by gamma motor neurons, which innervate the intrafusal muscle fibers and regulate their sensitivity to stretch. This allows the muscle spindle to adjust and respond to changes in muscle length, contributing to proprioceptive feedback and reflex control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha neuron: Innervates extrafusal muscle fibers responsible for muscle contraction and generating force, not the muscle spindle itself.

 

Option C. Beta neuron: Innervates both intrafusal and extrafusal muscle fibers, but their role is less prominent compared to alpha and gamma neurons and not the primary motor supply for muscle spindles.

 

Option D. Delta neuron: This term is not commonly used to describe motor neurons in the somatic system; it is generally associated with sensory neurons or other classifications, thus not relevant here.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

 

Fig: Signal transduction in taste receptors: Salt and sour tastes are mediated via the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This receptor has two subunits (a and g), each crossing the membrane twice, resulting in intracellular N and C termini (NT, CT). Salt is sensed following Na+ movement; sour is mediated by movement of H+. Sweet, bitter, and umami tastes are sensed via G-protein-coupled receptors that span the membrane seven times and have varying lengths of CT and NT (represented as ribbon structures). Sweet tastes are detected by the T1R2 and T1R3 families, bitter and umami tastes are detected by the T2R family and mGluR4, respectively.

 

Fig: Receptors on nociceptive unmyelinated nerve terminals in the skin. Nociceptive stimuli (eg, heat) can activate some receptors directly due to transduction of the stimulus energy by receptors (eg, transient receptor potential (TRP) channel TRPV1) or indirectly by activation of TRP channels on keratinocytes (eg, TRPV3). Nociceptors (eg, mechanoreceptors) can also be activated by the release of intermediate molecules (eg, ATP), ASIC, acid-sensitive ion channel; P2X, ionotropic purinoceptor, P2Y, G-protein-coupled purinergic receptor.

 

Sour taste is primarily mediated by the detection of H+ ions, which are present in acidic substances like citric acid. These H+ ions activate ion channels rather than G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Specifically, the TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Receptor Type 1) channel and acid-sensitive ion channels are involved in mediating the sour taste. These channels open in response to the presence of H+ ions, allowing the ions to enter the taste cells, which leads to the perception of a sour taste.

 

Metabotropic receptors, which involve GPCRs, mediate other taste modalities like sweet, bitter, and umami but are not involved in sour taste. The GPCR T1R1 and T1R3 are specifically involved in the sweet and umami taste pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabotropic Receptor: This type of receptor is associated with GPCRs and mediates taste sensations like sweet, bitter, and umami. It is not involved in sour taste, which is mediated by ion channels.

 

Option C. GPCR T1R1: This receptor is part of the GPCR family and is involved in detecting umami (savory) tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Option D. GPCR T1R3: This receptor is also a part of the GPCR family and contributes to the detection of sweet and umami tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

choices.text: ATP binding site is located intracellularly
K⁺ binding site is on the extracellular side
Ouabain binds to the cytoplasmic domain

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase structure, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ouabain binds to the cytoplasmic domain

 

Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase is a transmembrane pump that maintains ionic gradients across the plasma membrane. The ATP binding site and phosphorylation site are located intracellularly, while K⁺ binding occurs extracellularly. Ouabain, a cardiac glycoside, inhibits the pump by binding to the extracellular domain, not the cytoplasmic side.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ATP binding site is located intracellularly: True, fuels the pump.
 

Option B. K⁺ binding site is on the extracellular side: True, K⁺ enters from outside.
 

Option D. Phosphorylation site is intracellular: True, phosphorylation drives conformational change.

choices.text: Passive tension increases with muscle stretch
Active tension is highest at optimal length
Total tension equals sum of passive and active tension
Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length

questions.text: All are correct statements about muscle tension curves, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length

 

Passive tension develops only when a muscle is stretched beyond its resting length, due to elastic elements (like titin). At resting length, passive tension is minimal or absent. Active tension is maximal at the muscle’s optimal length, and total tension is the sum of both active and passive components.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Passive tension increases with muscle stretch: True, rises exponentially after resting length.
 

Option B. Active tension is highest at optimal length: True, due to maximum actin-myosin overlap.
 

Option C. Total tension equals sum of passive and active tension: True, reflects combined forces.

questions.text: Match the neurotransmitter with its correct receptor type:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GABA-A - Ionotropic 

 

GABA-A is a ligand-gated chloride ion channel, hence ionotropic.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Glycine – G-Protein Coupled Receptor: Glycine receptor is ionotropic (Cl⁻ channel), not GPCR.
 

Option C. Nicotinic – G-Protein Coupled Receptor: Nicotinic ACh receptor is ionotropic (Na⁺/K⁺ channel).
 

Option D. GABA-B – Ionotropic: GABA-B is metabotropic (GPCR), not ionotropic.

questions.text: The serotonergic cell bodies of the analgesia pathway projecting to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord are located in which part of the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleus raphe

 

The descending pain modulation pathway originates in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), which activates the nucleus raphe magnus (a raphe nucleus in the medulla). The raphe nuclei contain serotonergic neurons that project to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord to inhibit pain transmission.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Periaqueductal gray area: Initiates descending pain inhibition but not the main serotonergic cell body site.
 

Option B. Rostral ventromedial medulla: Includes the raphe nuclei, but serotonergic cell bodies are specifically in nucleus raphe magnus.
 

Option C. Locus ceruleus: Noradrenergic center, not serotonergic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for COPD in a patient with dementia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tiotropium

 

Tiotropium is an inhaled long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) used in COPD. Since it is inhaled and acts locally in the lungs, it causes minimal systemic anticholinergic effects, making it safer in elderly patients with dementia, where central anticholinergic drugs worsen cognition.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Tolterodine: Used for overactive bladder; systemic anticholinergic, worsens dementia.


Option C. Telenzepine: Antimuscarinic for peptic ulcers, not used in COPD.


Option D. Tropicamide: Short-acting mydriatic used in eye exams, not for COPD.

choices.text: It does not bind to albumin

questions.text: A new aminoglycoside antibiotic is developed that is believed to be particularly effective against Pseudomonas. The volume of distribution of the drug is measured in a group of volunteers and is determined to be 4.5 L. This new drug is most likely to have which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is highly charged
 

The drug’s volume of distribution (Vd) is only 4.5 L, which is close to plasma volume (≈3–5 L). This means the drug stays mainly in the plasma and does not distribute into tissues. Such a property is typical of hydrophilic, highly charged molecules like aminoglycosides, which cannot cross lipid membranes.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. It has low molecular weight: Alone does not explain low Vd; small molecules can still diffuse widely.
 

Option B. It is lipophilic: Would increase tissue penetration → high Vd, not low.
 

Option C. It does not bind to albumin: Would increase free drug fraction, usually leading to higher tissue distribution, not restricted plasma distribution.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after developing sudden-onset right-side weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and has been taking warfarin for the past several years with a stable prothrombin time. His wife adds that he started taking a new drug 2 weeks ago, but she does not remember its name. Transesophageal echocardiogram reveals a small thrombus in the left atrium. This patient most likely started taking which of the following drugs recently?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) St John's wort

 

Warfarin is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes.

 

  • St John’s wort is a potent CYP450 inducer, which increases the metabolism of warfarin → decreases its plasma levels → reduces anticoagulant effect → increased risk of thromboembolism (like this patient’s atrial thrombus and stroke).

 

Other Options:


Option A. Amiodarone: CYP450 inhibitor → increases warfarin effect → ↑ risk of bleeding, not clotting.


Option B. Cimetidine: CYP450 inhibitor → increases warfarin levels → ↑ bleeding risk.


Option C. Ciprofloxacin: also inhibits CYP450 → ↑ warfarin effect and bleeding tendency.

choices.text: Cannot be determined from the image

questions.text: Identify the drug pharmacokinetics from the graph:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) First order kinetics 

 

The graph shows a linear relationship between rate of elimination and drug concentration. This is characteristic of first order kinetics, where a constant proportion of the drug is eliminated per unit time, and the rate depends directly on the drug concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zero order kinetics: The rate of elimination is constant regardless of the drug concentration (graph shows a horizontal line), seen in drugs like phenytoin and ethanol when their elimination pathways are saturated.

 

Option C. Second order kinetics: Relates to reactions where the rate depends on the square of the concentration of one reactant or on two different reactants, not typically used for drug elimination graphs in pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male as a maintenance dose. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/ mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 60 ng/min 

 

We use the formula for maintenance dosing rate:

 

 

Step= Multiply concentration × clearance and divide by F

 

0.70 ng/mL×60 mL/min divided by 0.7=60 ng/min

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

In a patient with enterococcal endocarditis who is allergic to penicillin, vancomycin is the drug of choice as it covers Enterococcus and is safe in penicillin allergy.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Aztreonam: Active mainly against gram-negative rods; no activity against enterococci.


Option C. Ceftriaxone: A β-lactam, can cross-react in severe penicillin allergy and is not reliably effective against enterococcus.


Option D. Piperacillin: Penicillin derivative; contraindicated in penicillin allergy.

choices.text: Carboline at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor

questions.text: Match the following drugs-receptor combination appropriate for A
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carboline at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor

 

The graph shows both positive and negative responses relative to the baseline (0) as drug concentration increases. This is characteristic of an inverse agonist, which produces a response below the baseline by decreasing constitutive receptor activity. Carboline acts as an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor, leading to negative intrinsic activity reflected in the lower half of the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salbutamol at beta-2 receptor: Acts as an agonist, producing a positive response above baseline, not as an inverse agonist.

 

Option B. Naloxone at opioid receptors: Functions as a competitive antagonist, blocking receptor activation but does not induce a negative response below baseline.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine at opioid receptor: Acts as a partial agonist, producing less than maximal positive response, not a negative or inverse response.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) β1 agonist and β2 agonist

 

The drug's likely mechanism of action is β1 and β2 agonism.

 

Due to its action on β1 receptors, there is an increase in the HR of the patient and also of the SBP (Increase in HR leads to an increase in the CO upto a certain extent). The agonistic action on the β2 receptors causes vasodilation and leads to a fall in the DBP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α1 agonist and β1 agonist: α1 agonists typically cause vasoconstriction, which would increase both SBP and DBP. This does not align with the observed decrease in DBP.

 

Option B. M2 agonist and M3 agonist: M2 and M3 receptor agonism would likely lead to bradycardia and increased gastrointestinal motility, respectively. They do not explain the observed increase in HR and SBP, nor the decrease in DBP.

 

Option C. α1 antagonist and β2 agonist: While α1 antagonism could contribute to a decrease in DBP through vasodilation, it would not typically cause an increase in SBP and HR, which are more specifically associated with β1 agonism.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not require dose reduction in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doxycycline

 

Doxycycline is an antibiotic that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal failure because it is primarily excreted in the bile and not significantly through the kidneys. This makes it safer for use in patients with impaired renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentamicin: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, the clearance of gentamicin is significantly reduced, and therefore, dose adjustments are necessary to avoid toxicity, particularly nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.
