Option B. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic that is also primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are required to prevent accumulation of the drug and subsequent nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that can cause nephrotoxicity. Although its dose does not typically require adjustment based solely on renal function, careful monitoring and possible dose adjustment are often necessary to manage its renal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drugs which are secreted in bile and safe in renal disease include:

 

Cef in: Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone

 

The: Tigecycline

 

R: Rifampicin

 

E: Erythromycin

 

N: Nafcillin

 

A: Ampicillin

 

L: Lincosamide (Clindamycin)

 

D: Doxycycline

questions.text: A manufacturer substitutes a drug partly by another drug and doesn’t add it in the label. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spurious drug

 

A drug is termed spurious if it is wholly or partly substituted by another drug or substance and not labeled accordingly.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Misbranded drug: A drug with false/misleading claims on label/packaging (not about substitution).


Option B. Adulterated drug: A drug prepared under unhygienic/contaminated conditions or containing harmful/toxic substances.


Option C. Unethical drug: Drugs promoted/marketed in a manner violating medical ethics, not related to substitution.

questions.text: A new antibiotic developed for the treatment of infections caused by resistant gram-positive cocci has a volume of distribution of 11L. It is eliminated by first-order kinetics and has a half-life of 10 hours. If given by a continuous infusion, approximately how much time would it require for the drug to achieve a 95% plasma steady state concentration?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 40 hours

 

  • Time to reach steady state (Css) with first-order kinetics depends only on the drug’s half-life (t½).
  • Steady state ≈ 4–5 half-lives.
  • Here, t½ = 10 hours →
    • 1 half-life = 50%
    • 2 half-lives = 75%
    • 3 half-lives = 87.5%
    • 4 half-lives = 93.75% (~95%)
  • Therefore, ≈ 4 × 10 hours = 40 hours.

questions.text: Physiologists conduct a series of experiments on hypophysectomized animals to investigate the effects of cortisol on vascular reactivity. Their initial tests show that administration of cortisol alone does not elicit a vascular response. Next, the researchers measure vascular reactivity to an infusion of norepinephrine both with and without pretreatment with cortisol. The results of their experiments are shown in the graph below. Which of the following pharmacologic principles best describes the effect of cortisol in this experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Permisiveness

 

The graph illustrates that cortisol alone does not elicit a vascular response, but pretreatment with cortisol enhances the response to norepinephrine. This exemplifies the pharmacologic principle of permissiveness, in which one hormone (cortisol) increases the effectiveness of another (norepinephrine) without itself producing the response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Additive effect: This occurs when the combined effect of two drugs equals the sum of their individual effects; here, cortisol alone produces no direct response, so this doesn't apply.

 

Option B. Synergistic effect: When two drugs together produce an effect greater than the sum of their individual effects; in this case, cortisol enhances norepinephrine’s effect but does not have an effect by itself, so it's not synergism.

 

Option D. Tachyphylaxis: Refers to a rapid decrease in response to a drug after repeated administration, which is not shown in the experiment or graph

questions.text: A 45 year old male with erectile dysfunction was prescribed sildenafil. He develops bluish-green vision. Inhibition of which enzyme is the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphodiesterase 6

 

Sildenafil primarily inhibits PDE5 to treat erectile dysfunction, but cross-inhibition of PDE6 in retinal photoreceptors leads to bluish-green vision disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphodiesterase 3: Found in heart & vascular smooth muscle; inhibition affects contractility, not color vision.

 

Option B. Phosphodiesterase 5: Main target for erectile dysfunction; doesn’t cause visual side effects directly.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase 2: Found in heart and CNS; unrelated to visual perception.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs act on the same receptor but have opposite effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diazoxide and nateglinide

 

Diazoxide opens pancreatic K⁺ ATP channels (↓ insulin release), whereas nateglinide closes them (↑ insulin release). Both act on the same receptor (K⁺ ATP channel) but produce opposite effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin & octreotide: Both inhibit hormone secretion, similar effect.

 

Option B. Thioridazine & haloperidol: Both dopamine antagonists, same effect.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone & gemfibrozil: Act on different receptors (PPAR-γ vs PPAR-α).

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched drug-induced liver pathologies, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methotrexate – Cholestatic pattern

 

Methotrexate primarily causes hepatic fibrosis and cirrhosis, not cholestatic injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate – Microvesicular steatosis: Valproate → Microvesicular steatosis (Reye-like).

 

Option B. Halothane – Massive necrosis: Halothane → Massive hepatic necrosis.

 

Option D. Allopurinol – Fibrin ring granulomas: Allopurinol → Fibrin ring granulomas (rare hypersensitivity).

questions.text: Match the incorrect pair of drugs and enzyme/reaction they inhibit:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5FU: Dihydrofolate reductase

 

5-FU inhibits thymidylate synthase, not DHFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: PRPP synthetase: Azathioprine → Inhibits purine synthesis via PRPP amidotransferase.

 

Option B. Mycophenolate: IMP → GMP conversion: Mycophenolate → Inhibits IMP dehydrogenase (IMP → GMP).

 

Option C. Leflunomide: Carbamoyl phosphate → Orotic acid: Leflunomide → Inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase in pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.text: All of the following anti-retroviral drugs are given orally except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ibalizumab

 

Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody given IV, not orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Efavirenz: NNRTI, oral.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: Oral gp120 attachment inhibitor.

 

Option D. Abacavir: NRTI, oral.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment wellness examination. A tuberculin skin test is administered and he develops a raised, erythematous 12 mm lesion on his forearm within 48 hours. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. He is started on the recommended antibiotic treatment for latent tuberculosis. Four weeks later, he returns for a follow-up examination. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, serum alanine aminotransferase activity of 86 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase activity of 66 U/L. A photomicrograph of a Prussian blue-stained bone marrow smear is shown. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis

 

The Prussian blue-stained bone marrow photomicrograph shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors containing iron-laden mitochondria. This is a classic finding in sideroblastic anemia, which can be caused by isoniazid toxicity—a drug used for latent tuberculosis. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis and can lead to pyridoxine deficiency, impairing heme synthesis and causing iron accumulation in the mitochondria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase: Sulfonamides, not used for TB.

 

Option B. Binding to 50S ribosomal subunit: Macrolides/chloramphenicol.

 

Option D. Inhibition of arabinosyltransferase: Ethambutol, another TB drug but not linked to sideroblastic anemia.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the variability in drug metabolism across individuals using isoniazid. Variation in which of the following metabolic processes is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylation

 

The graph shows a bimodal distribution of plasma isoniazid (INH) concentrations among individuals, representing populations of slow and fast acetylators. Acetylation is mediated by the N-acetyltransferase enzyme, which exhibits genetic polymorphism leading to classification of individuals as slow or fast acetylators, directly explaining the bimodal plasma concentrations of isoniazid. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation is a phase II metabolic reaction that involves transferring a methyl group to substrates, often leading to detoxification or alteration of activity. While methylation occurs with many drugs, it is not the primary pathway responsible for the variability in isoniazid metabolism or plasma concentration differences seen in populations.

 

Option B. Hydrolysis: Hydrolysis involves cleavage of chemical bonds through the addition of water, commonly seen in ester or amide bonds. This reaction is important for activating or deactivating some drugs, but it is not a significant metabolic pathway for isoniazid, hence not contributing to its variable plasma levels.

 

Option D. Glucuronidation: Glucuronidation is a major phase II conjugation reaction that attaches glucuronic acid to lipophilic molecules to enhance excretion. It typically affects drugs like morphine or bilirubin but is not the key metabolic step for isoniazid nor responsible for its polymorphic metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following organs can differentiate between the action of epinephrine and nor-epinephrine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchus

 

Bronchial smooth muscle expresses β2-adrenoceptors, which respond preferentially to epinephrine over norepinephrine, allowing differentiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrioventricular node: Responds to both via β1 receptors; doesn’t distinguish.

 

Option B. Iris of the eye: Both cause pupil dilation/constriction via α/β receptors; limited differentiation.

 

Option D. Renal juxtaglomerular apparatus: β1 receptor-mediated renin release; minimal differentiation.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor PCM (paracetamol) toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rumack Matthew

 

The Rumack-Matthew nomogram is used to assess risk of hepatotoxicity after acute paracetamol overdose based on plasma concentration vs time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matzke: Used for aminoglycoside dosing.

 

Option C. Hartford: Not relevant for paracetamol.

 

Option D. Naranjo: Adverse drug reaction probability scale.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs need labelling as “Dangerous to use except under medical supervision”?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule G drugs

 

Schedule G drugs  require a warning: Caution: It is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schedule H drugs: Prescription drugs, no specific wording.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs: Drugs exempted from patent or licensing rules.

 

Option D. Schedule X drugs: Narcotics/psychotropic requiring special prescription.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the reactivation of infections they are associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Bortezomib → HSV reactivation (common in multiple myeloma patients).
  2. Rituximab → Hepatitis B reactivation.
  3. TNF-α inhibitors → TB reactivation.
  4. Fingolimod → Herpes zoster virus (HZV) reactivation.
